Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Emergence of Stakeholders and Ecosystems as Powerful Actors in Marine Spatial Planning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Determining how to effectively and responsibly manage the oceans is a complex task, engaging researchers, policymakers, and others for decades. In response to past and existing forms of oceans management, Marine Spatial Planning (MSP) is an emerging process of oceans governance that seeks to address current concerns with how to organize and use the nation's marine resources. MSP is a central component of the US federal government's National Ocean Policy, and is the key avenue through which the government's commitment to ecosystem-based management of the oceans will be realized. The marine environment is home to a growing number of users and activities that MSP is working to frame within a new comprehensive planning process. This research project will improve understanding of the processes of ocean governance produced within the context of MSP, ones critical to sustaining coastal communities and the marine resources many of them depend on.

The research will focus on two key questions: 1) How are communities and environmental actors constituted by MSP practices?; and 2) What are the roles of community and environmental actors in the constitution of MSP itself? Through these, the research will examine how national policy language for MSP is interpreted in regional MSP discourses and practices, how the concerns of practitioners and human interest groups are formulated and addressed, and how the widely varying marine environmental actors both within and between regions - such as fish, marine mammals, or sea grasses - are inscribed. Within these regions, there are specific sites, or 'centers of calculation, that will be the focus of data collection. These include online ocean science databases (both national and regional); regional MSP consortiums in the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast; and research centers that have been instrumental in the 'turn' toward MSP, ecosystems, and ecosystem services. The project will collect written and audio records from regional government agencies, non-government organizations, industry groups, and public forums; collect source data and outputs from the various mapping projects associated with MSP; and conduct short organizational ethnographies of the organizations leading these projects. The project will analyze what types of human and marine resource information are being incorporated into MSP (and what might be missing), a critical need as researchers and policymakers move forward with ever-larger data sets designed to visualize and organize US ocean uses. Practically, the project aims to inform MSP practices as communities across the country continue to engage with initiatives (e.g., aquaculture, catch shares, wind energy) that define ocean space in different ways. More generally, there is unprecedented worldwide interest in new forms of oceans governance, and although this research will focus on the US, results will have significance for these larger processes. The project will strengthen existing collaborations across academic institutions and with government and community groups, and contributes to post-doctoral training and mentoring. Results will be communicated to academic, practitioners, and community audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to examine the policy evolution of Marine Spatial Planning (MSP) in the United States, focusing on communities and environmental actors, and the shift from national policy to regional implementation. In the specific regional cases of the North East Regional Planning Body and the Mid-Atlantic Regional Planning Body, we examined how national policy language was interpreted, how the concerns of practitioners and human interest groups were formulated, and how the widely varying marine environmental actors both within and between regions were inscribed within regional online data portals.

This NSF award allowed us to analyze MSP policy documents (both federal and regional); interview key players in the design and implementation of regional MSP, and in particular of the regional online data portals; attend formal meetings of the Regional Planning Boards; attend various public events where MSP implementation strategies were discussed and regional online data portals demonstrated; and explore in-depth the case of wind energy in the mid-Atlantic (VA), where the implementation of a regional planning approach has been most explicit to date. Our findings speak to: the role of MSP in ocean enclosure; the challenges of using spatial technologies to characterize human-ocean relationships; the uptake and use of planning products by communities; the role of some environmental features and species (e.g. marine mammals, sea turtles) in shaping the MSP process; the rescaling of MPS from a national to regional project; the social and policy work facilitated by MSP; and, more broadly, what the MSP experience in the US can tell us about the nature of contemporary environmental governance.

These findings have been (and will be further) detailed in peer-reviewed publications. We have both organized and been invited to participate in panels devoted to marine governance and MSP at national and international academic conferences, and are part of an emerging informal network of international researchers interested in the broader context of MSP and what it accomplishes (versus the technical aspects of MSP).  Project aims were shared with practitioners through a project fact sheet circulated directly to individuals, opportunistically, during the course of the research. Detailed information on the project and findings are also shared on a project web site (sites.duke.edu/planning) and Research Gate project page. The project has sometimes served to bring MSP stakeholders together; for example, during field work in Maine, the project brought together representatives of NGOs, fishing organizations, and local government to discuss MSP. The PIs were invited to participate in an international expert working group convened to review progress with MSP in practice and how to assess this across cases; the workshop had the explicit goal of informing investments in MSP (by governments and philanthropic funders).

The project has provided advanced research training and networking opportunities for two post-doctoral research associates, and strengthened existing networks between researchers at Duke University, Rutger’s University, and Eckerd College. Although this project has ended, further collaboration is planned. Finally, team members have integrated MSP as a topic and our specific research results into teaching modules at all three institutions.
